justification: The Methods section lists the "Beck Depression Inventory 55 (BDI)" as one of the questionnaires selected "to span a range of internalizing negative affect dimensions," indicating it operationalizes depression severity.
Under Questionnaire measures the authors include the "Penn State Worry Questionnaire 52 (PSWQ)," explicitly using it to capture the construct of worry.
The battery is said to contain the "Mood and Anxiety Symptom Questionnaire (MASQ) anxious arousal (AA) subscale," showing this subscale indexes anxious-arousal symptoms.
The same sentence names the "MASQ anhedonic depression (AD) subscale," indicating it measures the anhedonic-depression construct.
The authors list "the State Trait Anxiety Inventory-Trait version (STAI-T) ... anxiety (Anx.) and depression (Dep.) subscales," identifying STAI-T as their instrument for trait anxiety.

measured_by: Apathy and Motivation Index (AMI) behavioral subscale
justification: They specify use of "Apathy and Motivation Index 23 behavioral subscale (AMI Beh.)," directly linking this subscale to the behavioral apathy construct.

measured_by: Temporal Experience of Pleasure Scale – anticipatory subscale (TEPS)
justification: The questionnaire list includes the "Temporal Experience of Pleasure 50 anticipatory hedonia subscale (TEPS Ant.)," which the study later reverses to index greater anticipatory anhedonia.

In the Introduction the EEfRT is described as "a human analog ... which pits a low effort/low reward option against a high effort/high reward option," and is used to study willingness to expend effort for reward.

measured_by: Apple-picking effort-based decision-making (EBDM) task – reward version
justification: The Results note "we adapted a previously used 'apple-picking' task … In the reward version, a successful outcome entails obtaining the trees' apples," indicating this task operationalises effortful pursuit of reward.

The authors created "a structurally equivalent aversive version of the task… participants avoid 'bear traps'… avoiding electrical stimulation," making this task a measure of effortful threat avoidance.

The Introduction explains that the FST "measures the amount of time the animal spends exerting initially vigorous physical effort in pursuit of escape," using it to assess effortful avoidance of threat in rodents.
construct: willingness to exert physical effort to escape/avoid threat
